title: Meatball and Mushroom Stew
description: Comforting, familiar and warm. It’s a timeless dish that never goes out of fashion.
instructions: Peel and cut potatoes, then boil with salt
Slice mushrooms
Pre-heat oven at 450°F
Wrap garlic in foil
Combine beef, breadcrumbs, 1/2 parmesan, onion powder, S&P, in a large bowl
Roll beef mixture into balls. Bake with garlic. 8-10 mins
Large pot high heat, add 1/2 butter
Add mirepoix and mushrooms. 5-6 mins. Add soy sauce, flour, S&P
Add broth and peas. Simmer 5-6 mins
Drain potatoes. Mash garlic in. Add remaining parmesan, butter and milk
Add meatballs to the stew. 1 min
Divide mash between bowls. Top with meatball and mushroom stew.

title: Onsen Tamago
description: Perfectly poached inside its shell. While the whites are soft and silky, the yolk comes out firm but retains the color and creamy texture of an uncooked yolk.
instructions: Only cook 4 refrigirated eggs per batch. Increasing/decreasing the number of eggs will greatly affect the result
Small/medium pot, boil 4.25 cup of water covered
Remove from heat once boiling, then add 0.75 cups of tap water. Gently submerge the eggs. cover and set timer for 17 mins.

title: Taiwanese Chicken Thighs
description: These saucy chicken thighs celebrate all of those things and more, with a side of scallion rice and crispy bok choy!
instructions: Debone and slice chicken in desired sizes. Pat dry. S&P
Rinse and chop Bok-choy
Cook rice. Use 1:2 water ratio. High heat, uncovered until boiling, then cover and simmer under lowest heat setting
Slice green onions. Grate garlic
Whisk together vinegar, soy, cornstartch, garlic & sugar
Large wok on med-high. Add sesame oil, then chicken. Cook for about 7-8 min
Add sauce, then add bok-choy. Cook 1-2 mins
Fluff rice and add half the green onions.
Assemble. Top with basil, chili flakes and remaining green onions

title: Hard Boiled Eggs
description: Simple way to perfectly hard-boil eggs to the desired doneness.
instructions: Refrigirated eggs to a small pot. Add water until fully covered by atleast an inch
High heat, uncovered, bring to rolling boil
Once boiling, turn off heat and set aside covered. 10-15 mins depending on desired doneness.

title: Teriyaki Beef Meatballs
description: Super simple and packed with delectable flavours. The colourful slaw will surprise you with its Japanese vibes and sweet crunchy veggies!
instructions: Cook Rice in a small pot. 1 rice : 2 water ratio. First boil uncovered. Once boiling, cover and simmer at a very low heat.
Zest lemon. Slice green onions.
Preheat oven at 450°F
Make meatballs: Combine ground beef, spice blend(per serving: 1 tbsp garlic powder, 1tbsp onion powder, 0.5tbsp ginger powder), breadcrumbs and S&P. Roll into balls and arrange in a baking pan.
Once oven is pre-heated, bake the meatballs, 10-12 min
Coleslaw mix: In a large bowl, juice lemon, then whisk in mayo, 1tbsp sugar and S&P. Add coleslaw and mix
Create Teriyaki Sauce: Med pot med heat. Add in soy sauce, hoisin sauce, sesame oil, mirin and 1/4 cup water. Cook 1-2 mins
Add meatballs to the sauce. Cook 1-2 mins.
Fluff rice with 1 tbsp oil, 1/2 green onions and fried garlic.
Assemble. Top with the remaining green onions. Slaw on the side

title: Oven Barbecue Ribs
description: Juicy melt-in-your-mouth oven baked Barbecue Ribs are fall-off-the-bone delicious! Double up on incredible flavour with an easy to make dry rub first, then coat them in a seasoned barbecue sauce mixture so addictive you won’t stop at one!
instructions: Heat oven to 275° Fahrenheit (135C)
If the ribs still have the thin membrane covering the back of the rack, remove it
Season both sides of the ribs with a generous amount of salt, pepper or any rub of choice. Place the ribs, meat-side up, into a large roasting pan or rimmed baking sheet.
Cover the pan or baking sheet tightly with aluminum foil, and then bake until the meat is tender or falls easily from the bones, 2 ½ to 3 ½ hours.
Remove the ribs from the oven, discard the aluminum foil and generously brush both sides with barbecue sauce of choice (optional).

Optional: Move an oven rack near the top of the oven. Turn broiler to high and broil the ribs for 3-4 minutes, just until the barbecue sauce begins to caramelize. (Keep a close eye on the ribs while they broil so the sauce does not burn.)

title: Chinese Steamed Fish
description: Cantonese steamed fish is a traditional, simple dish often served as one of the final courses in a Chinese wedding banquet

fish-fillet.name: Fish Fillet, Haddock, Cod or Sea Bass

instructions: Slice aromatics. Twine one scallion, then julliene the rest. Slice and/or julliene ginger
Add shallow water into a pot or wok. Let boil.
Place a small plate/bowl in the middle of the pot, then add twined scallion.
Add a piece of fish fillet on top of the twined scallion, then sprinkle with julliened ginger. Cover and steam for 7-8 minutes
Create Sauce: Small pot, add soy sauce, same amount of water, pinch of sugar, few slices of ginger and white part of the scallions. 1 min, then transfer to a plate.
After 8 minutes, remove the plate from heat. Discard aromatics, then pour over sauce
Create ginger oil: Heat a pan and add some oil, then fully julliened ginger. Cook till golden brown. Drizzle over ginger oil

title: Pork Chashu
description: Japanese have adapted the famous Chinese barbecued pork called Char Siu (叉燒) as chāshū (チャーシュー). Unlike the Chinese version which requires roasting over high heat, we prepare the meat by rolling it into a log and then braising it over low heat in a sauce seasoned with soy sauce, sake, and sugar.
instructions: Prepare and season the pork slab. Roll using butcher's twine(optional)
Heat the oil in a cast-iron skillet (or regular frying pan) over high heat. Sear the pork
While the pork is searing, put all the ingredients for the seasonings in a heavy-bottomed pot that will fit the chashu.
Add water equal to the soy sauce - sake mixture. Add a good amount sugar.
Transfer the seared chashu to the pot. Bring to a boil, then lower the heat to simmer.
Put an otoshibuta (drop lid) on top to press the ingredients down and limit the evaporation. If you don’t have an otoshibuta, you can make one with aluminum foil or baking sheet
Simmer the chashu for 2 hours, turning the chashu every 30 minutes
Let it cool, then transfer chashu and sauce to a large ziplock back. Displace the air and seal. Let the meat marinate overnight
Excess sauce can be used to make Ramen Eggs (Ajitsuke Tamago).

title: Ramen Eggs
description: Ramen eggs are Japanese soft-boiled eggs known for its custardy jammy egg yolk and umami flavor. They are marinated overnight in a sweetened soy-based sauce. In Japan, we call these marinated eggs Ajitsuke Tamago (味付け玉子) or short for Ajitama (味玉) or Nitamago (煮玉子).
instructions: Make the marinade. The best way is to use excess sauce from the chashu recipe. Otherwise, combine all the ingredients in a small saucepan.
Add water equal to the amount of soy sauce-mirin mixture. Whisk and add 1 tbsp sugar. Boil
Once boiling, simmer for 1 min. set aside to cool off.
Make the eggs. In a small pot, boil water. Add a bit of vinegar and salt to make peeling easier later.
Once boiling, set a timer for 7 minutes, then slowly add the eggs.
After 7 minutes, immediately take out the eggs and shock them in an iced water for 15 minutes. Peel
Transfer eggs and sauce to a ziplock back. Displace the air and seal. Let the eggs marinate overnight

title: Aroma Oil
description: Ramen eggs are Japanese soft-boiled eggs known for its custardy jammy egg yolk and umami flavor. They are marinated overnight in a sweetened soy-based sauce. In Japan, we call these marinated eggs Ajitsuke Tamago (味付け玉子) or short for Ajitama (味玉) or Nitamago (煮玉子).
instructions: Slice garlic and onions.
All ingredients in to a pot on medium heat
Once hot, let it sit on low heat for 30 mins to 1 hour. Make sure not to burn them.
Drain the oil in to a container. Refrigiration not needed.
Collect the toasted aromatics. They can be used as toppings to almost any dish.

title: Shoyu Tare
description: Tare is one of the most important ingredients in a good bowl of ramen. It is the concentrated base that enhances the soup by adding salt and flavor. When you go to most ramen shops, you’ll often find the ramen categorized by tare.
instructions: Slice konbu into strips
Optional: Grind dried seafood and shiitake into chunks or powder
Put about 2.5 cups of water in a large stockpot and add the konbu. Bring it to a boil. Simmer for 2 minutes, then remove and discard the konbu.

Add the fish-and-mushroom powder to the simmering water and bring it to a boil again. When it boils, remove from the heat and strain the liquid through a paper or cloth filter (a coffee filter works well for this)
If measuring the salt by weight, measure the weight of the liquid using a kitchen scale. Mix 17% of this weight in salt.
Pour the liquid-and-salt mixture into a measuring cup, then transfer to a large bowl. Measure out the same amount of soy sauce and add it to the bowl. Mix well.
The tare will keep in an airtight container in the refrigerator for a few months.

title: Gyudon
description: Thinly sliced beef and tender onions cooked in savory-sweet sauce, Gyudon, or Japanese Beef Rice Bowl, is synonymous with comfort. It has been a staple in Japanese cuisine for over 150 years! It’s a perfect quick meal for a busy weeknight!
instructions: Thinly slice onions. Slice scallions diagonally. Grate ginger.
Slice meat into 3 inch pieces
In a large frying pan (do not turn on the heat yet), add the dashi, sake, mirin, soy sauce, and a pinch of sugar. Mix to combine.
Add the onion slices and spread them throughout the pan, separating the onion layers.
Add the meat on top of the onions. Separate the thin slices of beef so the meat covers the onions.
Cover the pan with a lid and start cooking over medium heat.
When the meat is cooked, skim off the scum and fat from the broth with a fine-mesh skimmer. Turn down the heat to simmer and continue cooking, covered, for 3-4 minutes.
Sprinkle the green onions on top and cook covered for another minute. If you like to add beaten eggs, you can add at this step
In a large donburi bowl, add the steamed rice and drizzle the remaining sauce on top.
Put the beef and onion mixture on top. If you’d like, drizzle the remaining sauce on top. Top with the pickled red ginger. Enjoy!

title: Tonkotsu Ramen Broth
description: Making tonkotsu ramen at home is truly a labour of love. This isn’t some 15 minute miracle insta-ramen recipe. This isn’t even some one day recipe. Making authentic tonkotsu ramen takes time. It takes effort. You have to be a bit crazy to go there. But it’s so good. It’s totally worth it.

pork-bones.name: Pork Bones, Pig Trotters and/or Chicken Carcass

instructions: Place bones in a large stockpot and cover with cold water. Boil. Remove from heat as soon as boil is reached.
While pot is heating, roughly slice aromatics. Set the green part of scallions aside for garnish. Sear the rest of the aromatics on a large pan on high heat. Set aside.
Once pot has come to a boil, dump water and wash all bones under cold running water, removing any bits of dark marrow or coagulated blood.

Return bones to pot along with charred vegetables, leeks, scallion whites, mushrooms, and pork fatback. Top up with cold water. Bring to a rolling boil over high heat, skimming off any scum that appears. Reduce heat to a bare simmer and place a heavy lid on top.

The broth should be at a slow rolling boil. If not, increase or decrease heat slightly to adjust. Remove pork fat once completely tender(about 4 hours), and refrigirate. Continue cooking until broth is opaque with the texture of light cream, about 6 to 8 hours longer, topping up as necessary.
Once broth is ready, cook over high heat until reduced to around 3 liters. Strain through a fine mesh strainer into a clean pot. Discard solids.
Finely chop cooked pork fatback and whisk into finished broth.

title: Dashi Stock
description: Dashi is the basic Japanese soup stock used in many Japanese dishes. Learn how to make Awase Dashi at home with umami-packed ingredients like kombu (dried kelp) and katsuobushi (dried bonito flakes).
instructions: Prepare Konbu: Slice kombu into pieces. Cold brew kombu overnight with about 1 liter of water
Add the konbu and water to a medium saucepan. Turn on the heat to medium low and slowly bring to almost boiling, about 10 minutes.
Just before the dashi starts boiling gently, remove and discard the konbu.
Add the katsuobushi and bring it back to a boil again.
Once the dashi is boiling, reduce the heat, simmer for just 30 seconds, and turn off the heat.
Let the katsuobushi sink to the bottom, about 10 minutes.
Strain the dashi through a fine-mesh sieve over a bowl or measuring cup.

title: Butter Lobster
description: With a touch of lemon, garlic, butter and oil, you’re minutes away from perfect, juicy, flavourful seared lobsters.
instructions: Roughly chop onions, parsely and thyme
Cook Lobster: Boil water and Sprite on a large wok. Add lobster, boild for 15 minutes.
Create sauce: Onions and butter into a pan. 1-2 mins
Add garlic and salt. 1 min
Add white wine and reduce in half
Add paprika, lemon zest and chopped herbs
Remove from heat and add lemon juice and more butter. Whisk. Grate with parmesan cheese
Assembly: Pre-heat oven at 400 F. Halve lobsters lengthwise. Deshell claws
Assemble to a baking rack meat side up, then pour over butter mixture
Bake 8-10 minutes

title: Prawn Tempura
description: Tempura is a well-known Japanese dish where vegetables or seafood are first dipped in a tempura batter and deep-fried in oil. The beautiful light and crispy golden cover is the signature look of the dish.
instructions: Deshell prawns. Make small incisions on each side to keep them straight when cooked. Coat with flour lightly
Batter: Beat egg into a large bowl. Add flour, and for every cup of flour, add the same amount of water.
Mix the batter, but don't overmix the flour, leaving few tiny bits undissolved. Chill for 30 minutes
On a frying pan, add oil and heat to 350F.
Dip prawn in the batter one at a time, then fry. Add droplets of batter on top of the prawn to add extra crispy textures.
Tip: Make sure to keep the batter cold. Ice bath works well

title: Tinola
description: Tinola is an easy, one-pot soup from the Philippines. Chicken, chayote squash (or papaya!) and malunggay are simmered with fresh ginger in a savory broth that's often served with white rice.
instructions: Cut chicken into serving pieces. Pat dry
Chop onions. Grate garlic. Slice ginger into thin pieces
Saute garlic, onion and ginger. 2 minutes
Add in chicken and cook till lightly seared. 4 mins.
Add fish sauce and stir. Cook 1 mins.
Pour rice washing and let boil. Cover the pot and simmer for 45mins.
Add chayote. Cook for 5mins
Add the hot pepper leaves or malunggay leaves. Stir and cook for 1 minute.
Season with ground black pepper. Note you can also add more fish sauce or salt if needed.

title: Pork Sinigang
description: Sinigang is a Filipino soup or stew characterized by its sour and savory taste. It is most often associated with tamarind, although it can use other sour fruits and leaves as the souring agent. It is one of the more popular dishes in Filipino cuisine.
instructions: Chop onion. Grate garlic. Quarter tomatoes. Cut string beans into 2 inch pieces.
Saute onion and garlic.
Add pork and cook till lightly seared. Add fish sauce.
Add rice washing and bring to boil. Add gabi and tomatoes then simmer for 40 minutes or until pork is tender
Add in the sinigang mix and chili
Add the string beans (and other vegetables if there are any) and simmer for 5 to 8 minutes
Add the spinach, turn off the heat, and cover the pot. Let the spinach cook using the remaining heat in the pot.

title: Beef Papaitan
description: Papaitan is one of the popular Ilokano dishes and the original recipe calls for goat innards. The reason why it is called “papaitan” is because the dish is bitter by using goat bile as one of the ingredient but just enough to make it tasty. Since goat innards are not always available in the market, you can substitute it with beef innards.

beef-innards.name: Beef Innards(Tripe, Kidney, Heart, Intestines, Pancreas, Tendons)

instructions: Wash and mash the internal organs with salt to remove the musky odor. Make sure that the intestines are very clean.
Boil the internal organs on a big pot until tender. Add salt. Discard liquid then cut meat into 1/2 inch cubes. Set aside to dry.
Saute ginger, garlic and onion. Stir fry until the onions are cooked and add the internal organs.
Stir fry again until some broth comes out of the internal organs. Season with S&P and fish sauce.
Add just enough water to cover all the ingredients, then add beef cubes, jalapeno and papaitan mix. Bring to boil and simmer for 30 mins

title: Filipino Style Spaghetti
description: Filipino spaghetti is a Filipino adaptation of Italian spaghetti with Bolognese sauce. It has a distinctively sweet sauce, usually made from tomato sauce sweetened with brown sugar or banana ketchup. It is typically topped with sliced hot dogs or smoked longganisa sausages, giniling, and grated cheese.
instructions: Cook spaghetti according to package directions. Set aside.
Chop garlic and onions. Slice hotdogs
Place the garlic, onion, and oil in a large saucepan or skillet. Saute for 3-4 minutes or until soft and fragrant. Add the ground pork and brown the meat until it’s completely cooked.

Add the minced vegetables and hot dog pieces and stir to combine. Add 2 cups(per 2 servings) of water and allow the mixture to simmer for 10-15 minutes. Add the tomato sauce and tomato paste to the meat and continue to simmer the mixture for another 10-15 minutes. Add the evaporated milk and salt and stir until incorporated.
Combine pasta and sauce in a large pot or mixing bowl. Top with grated cheese.

title: Bulalo
description: Bulalô is a beef dish from the Philippines. It is a light colored soup that is made by cooking beef shanks and bone marrow until the collagen and fat has melted into the clear broth. It typically includes leafy vegetables, corn on the cob, scallions, onions, garlic, ginger, and fish sauce.
instructions: In a large pot, bring water to boil, then add beef. Continue boiling until no blood is coming out of the meat and bones. Discard water and clean the meat and bones off excess scum and blood.
Roughly chop onions and garlic
Using the same pot return the meat and bones, then add water, onion, garlic, peppercorn and fish sauce. Boil then simmer on low heat for 4-5 hours until meat is tender.
Add corn and simmer for few minutes.
Add in green beans and any veggies.
Best served with white rice, together with sawsawan(mix of fish sauce, chili and lemon juice)

title: Lomi
description: Lomi or Pancit Lomi is a Filipino dish made with a variety of thick fresh egg noodles of about a quarter of an inch in diameter, soaked in lye water to give it more texture.
instructions: Mince onion and garlic. Julienne carrots. Slice pork belly and chicken liver into 1 inch cubes
In a pot, bring enough water to cover noodles to a boil. Add noodles and blanch for about 1 minute. Drain and rinse in cold water.
In a pan over medium heat, heat about 1 tablespoon oil. Add liver and cook until just about done. Remove from pan and keep warm.
In the same pan, add 1 more tbsp of oil, then saute onion and garlic.
Add pork belly until lightly browned. Add fish sauce and cook for another 1 min.
Add about 8 cups of water and bring to a boil. Lower heat and simmer until pork is cooked through.
Add noodles and cook for about 3 to 5 minutes or until tender yet firm to bite.
Add crab and corn soup mix and stir to dissolve. Season with salt and pepper to taste.
Add liver and carrots and cook for about 1 to 2 minutes.
In a small bowl, combine corn starch and 1/4 cup cold water and stir to dissolve. Add to the pot, stirring to combine. Continue to cook for until slightly thickened.
In the same bowl, beat eggs. Add eggs slowly in a thin stream and allow to slightly set before stirring. Serve hot.

title: Beef Pares
description: Pares, also known as beef pares, is a term for a serving of Filipino braised beef stew with garlic fried rice, and a bowl of clear soup. It is a popular food particularly associated with specialty roadside diner-style establishments known as Pares Houses that specialize in serving these type of meals.
instructions: Pre boil the beef: Add 8-10 cups of water in a large pot and bring to a boil. Put the beef pieces in and let boil (on medium heat) for 5 minutes. Drain and rinse the meat in cold running water until there’s no more scum. Don’t omit this step to have a better broth.
Mince onions, garlic, ginger and green onions. Set aside.

On the same pot, add half the onion, half the ginger, half the star anise and pre-boiled beef”. Add 4 cups of water, cover and bring to a boil. Once boiling, remove the floating scum then lower the heat and cook until the meat is tender. 2 hours
Set all the tender meat aside (in a bowl) and transfer the beef broth into a smaller pot. Season the broth with S&P to taste

In a large pot, saute onion and ginger in oil then add the garlic. Put in the tender beef pieces and saute for a couple of minutes. Add in the brown sugar, soy sauce, star anise and 2 cups(per 4 servings) of prepared beef broth.

Bring to a boil then combine cornstarch and water (in a small bowl) to make the slurry. Pour over the stew, stir and simmer for 2 more minutes. Adjust seasoning, if needed. Sprinkle with sliced green onions (if using) before serving.
Serve Beef Pares with garlic fried rice and a bowl of beef broth. Enjoy!

title: Flash Fried Beef and Broccoli
description: This Flash Fried Beef and Broccoli recipe has been slightly tweaked from its original form in Jeremy's first cookbook ('Chinese Unchopped') where he used venison instead of the beef - but, spoiler: it's just as good! Think classic flavours, speedy wok cooking and one helluva sizzling stir-fry dish.
instructions: Slice the ginger and spring onions into fine matchsticks. Chop the broccoli or kai lan stems into thirds, then blanch them in boiling water for 2 minutes. Drain and set aside.

Slice the rib eye steak into large 1–2cm chunks, put them in a mixing bowl and add light soy, rice wine and sesame oil. Using your hands, massage the ingredients into the meat pieces until they are well coated, then add the cornflour and repeat until everything is well combined. For best results, leave the meat to marinade overnight in the fridge.
In a small bowl, mix tamarind concentrate, hoisin sauce, kecap manis and chicken stock.
Heat 1 tablespoon of vegetable oil in a wok over a high heat until smoking-hot. Add the ginger and half the spring onion and stir-fry for 1 minute, until the spring onions have softened.

Push the ingredients to the side of the wok, add the remaining ½ tablespoon of oil to the centre and return to smoking point. Add the steak, cover with the ginger and spring onions and stir-fry for 1 minute.

Add the broccoli, pour over the sauce and bring to a vigorous boil. Cook, stirring, for a further 30 seconds, then spoon into a serving bowl. Scatter over the remaining spring onion and the deep-fried shallots, if using, and serve.

title: Katsudon
description: Katsudon is a popular Japanese food, a bowl of rice topped with a deep-fried breaded pork cutlet, egg, vegetables, and condiments. The dish takes its name from the Japanese words tonkatsu and donburi.
instructions: Rub a pinch of salt and pepper onto both sides of the meat. Pound the pork chops to tenderize the meat, they should be about 2cm thick.
In a bowl, whisk the egg and 1 tbsp of milk/mayo.
Prepare two plates, one with flour and one with the panko breadcrumbs. Coat meat in this order: Flour-Egg-Breadcrumbs. Make sure to press meat to the breadcrumbs.
Heat the oil in a pan to 170C (340F) If you don't have a thermometer, just drop a piece of panko into the pan. When it's sizzling, you know the oil is ready.

Carefully place the coated pork chops into the oil and cook for about 4 minutes on each side (8 minutes total) or until golden brown. When the oil stops making a crackling sound, that usually means they're ready. Using food thermometer, internal temp must be above 145 ºF.
Cut one onion into thin slices and fry in a medium heat frying pan for a minute or so.
Add dashi, soy sauce, mirin and sake and pinch of sugar.
While onions cook, beat remaining eggs to a bowl.
Cut the katsu into 2cm strips, then add to the pan of onions.
Pour in beaten eggs, evenly distributing them over the katsu and onions.Leave to cook for 1-2 minutes.
Put a lid on top and turn off the heat. Allow the eggs to steam cook for 1 minute.
Assemble over white rice. Top with green onions

title: Chicken and Bacon Alfredo
description: An easy-breezy dinner inspired by a restaurant classic! Italian-seasoned chicken roasts in the oven, while the indulgent Parmesan cream sauce simmers away. Yum!
instructions: Mince onions. Chop chicken into 0.5 inch cubes. Slice bacon into 1/2 inch strips.

Preheat broiler. Add 10 cups water and 2 tsp salt in a large pot. Cover and bring to a boil over high heat. Cut bacon into 1/2-inch strips. Heat a large non-stick pan over medium-high heat. When hot, add bacon. Cook, stirring occasionally, until crispy, 5-7 min.** Remove pan from the heat. Using a slotted spoon, transfer bacon to a plate. Set aside, reserving 2 tbsp bacon fat in pan. Discard excess bacon fat..

While bacon cooks, break linguine in half and add to pot of boiling water. Cook uncovered, stirring occasionally, until tender, 10-12 min. When linguine is tender, reserve 1/2 cup pasta water, drain and return to same pot.

Pat chicken dry with paper towels. Toss chicken with Italian seasoning and 1 tbsp oil on a foil-lined baking sheet. Season with salt and pepper. Broil in the middle of the oven, stirring halfway through, until cooked through, 10-12 min.***

While chicken broils, heat the same pan (with bacon fat) over medium heat. When hot, add onions. Cook, stirring often, until caramelized. Add garlic powder and cream and simmer until sauce thickens slightly, 2-3 min.
To the pot with linguine, add cream sauce, spinach, reserved pasta water, half the parmesan and half the bacon. Stir until spinach wilts, 1 min. Season with pepper.
Divide linguine between plates. Top with chicken then sprinkle with remaining bacon and parmesan.

title: Hoisin-Glazed Pork Meatballs
description: Flavourful hoisin and sweet chili sauce make a luscious glaze for these Asian-style meatballs. Bright and tender-crisp veggies make this meal fresh and exciting on a weeknight.
instructions: Before starting, preheat the oven to 450°F. Wash and dry all produce. Add 1 cup water (1 3/4 cups for 4 ppl) to a medium pot. Cover and bring to a boil over high heat. Trim, then halve snap peas. Cut bok choy into 1-inch pieces. Thinly slice green onions. Peel, then mince or grate ginger.

Add the rice and coconut milk to pot with boiling water (NOTE: Keep your eye on the pot so it doesn't boil over). Reduce the heat to medium-low. Cover and cook until the rice is tender and the liquid has been absorbed, 12-14 min.

While rice cooks, combine half the ginger and ¼ tsp salt (dbl for 4 ppl) in a medium bowl. Season with pepper. Roll mixture into 8 equal meatballs (16 for 4 ppl). Transfer meatballs to a foil-lined baking sheet. Bake in the middle of the oven, until golden-brown and cooked through, 12-14 min.**

While meatballs bake, heat a large non-stick pan over medium-high heat. When hot, add 1 tbsp oil (dbl for 4 ppl), then snap peas. Cook, stirring often, until beginning to soften, 1-2 min. Add bok choy and remaining ginger. Cook, stirring often, until tender-crisp, 2-3 min. Season with salt and pepper. Remove pan from the heat, then transfer veggies to a plate and cover to keep warm.

While veggies cook, whisk together hoisin sauce, soy sauce, sweet chili sauce, cornstarch and 3/4 cups water (dbl for 4 ppl) in another medium bowl. When veggies are done, heat the same pan over medium heat. When hot, add hoisin mixture and cook, stirring often, until slightly thickened, 2-3 min. Add meatballs to pan with sauce, toss to coat.
Fluff coconut rice with a fork. Stir in half the green onions and season with salt. Divide rice among plates. Top with veggies, meatballs and sauce from the pan. Sprinkle with remaining green onions.
